item.description:
Game based on the use of magnetic marbles (clickets). The object is to place all the clickets on the game board (in the shape of a ruther), without moving them as a result of magnetic attraction.To determine to vacant place on the board where the clicket is to be put the players throw dice. Obviously the number of eyes on the dice determine the place to put the clicket.
The player who succeeds in placing his last clicket without disturbing the other marbles on the board wins the game.

This game features a picture of Hall Of Fame Coach Paul "Bear" Bryant. The game is a dice game where dice are used to determine the outcome of each play. Cards represent various plays for the defense to guess what the offense will choose. If the defense gets the correct play, any yardage gained is cut in half.

The box cover states "100 made in USA"

Battle Scenes is a Collectible Card Game produced by Copag - Companhia Paulista de Artes Gráficas and based upon the Marvel universe. 
The players must have a 60 card deck (up to 3 copies of each card) with at least 15 characters, and 30 or more health points in his deck. 
Each player draws 10 cards and can discard cards to his resource pile.
The objective of the game is to Knock-Out enemy characters for a total amount of 15 points of health.

The playing areas are: 

 Resources Area (Where the cards sent/discarded to resources go)
 Scene Area (Where the active characters, support and scenarios are played, until they're discarded or knocked-out)
 Prize Area (Where the knocked-out characters stay, counting points to the oposing player)




Here's the turn order:

COUNTDOWN PHASE
If the turn player doesn't have a character on the scene, he needs to discard the top card of his deck to the resource pile plus an additional card for each charater card your opponent has on the scene, plus an additional one for each character your opponent defeated (that is on his Prize Area).

PREPARATION PHASE
In this phase you can:

 discard one card from your hand to the resource pile (may only do this once a turn)
 charge a character that wasn't already charged this turn (may only do this once a turn)
 discard a card from your hand to charge a character that wasn't already charged this turn
 play a character or support card
 play a scenario. There can be only one card of this type at the table at a time, and this action can only be done once per turn
 knock-out your own character to buy a card
 discard a character you opponent has in play to draw a card




ADJUSTMENT PHASE
In this phase, you must discard down to 7 cards in hand and remove any excess cards on your characters.

COMBAT PHASE
In this phase, the players can pay charges on their characters to use the actions they have or to use the actions they are carrying.


 Antecipation Stage


First of all, the opposing player has the chance to perform his Antecipation Actions, as said in his characters cards.


 Attack Stage


Then the current player uses his actions by paying charges from his characters. Each character can only perform one action.

ENDING THE GAME
When a character is defeated, the cards attached to it are discarded to the resource area. Only the character goes to the prize area.
If, at any point in the game, a player has 15 points, he is the winner.

AWARDS


 2013 Ludo Award Winner (Editor's Choice and Popular)

item.description:
Pirate's Treasure (Pirackie Skarby) is a fast and simple game for 2-5 players.
In the middle of the table, there is 3x3 Treasure Island.

In each round, one player, places 5 Map Tiles, one by one. After last tile has been placed, players try to find a treasure on the island. They do that, by imagining road, from the middle of the island.

After 4 rounds, player with the most treasure is the winner.

item.description:
The first of the SB (Small Battles) series is also the first dedicated to the Napoleonic age. The game covers both the battle days with optional rules for the second one, making it possible for the Austrian player to avoid the moronic placement, the letargic leadership and pathetic planning of Argenteau that condamned the Austrian forces to a complete defeat.

Based on activation chits and operative orders, the game system features the different effects of formations on movement, fire and melee, forcing players to change their plans and to adapt their unit line of battle to respond to the enemy. Counters represent single batallions, batteries or skirmisher units.

item.description:
Lover'sopoly was created for the sole intended purpose of creating a game intended for married couples that most adult board games on the market today do not offer. Most adult board games today are very shallow and have no depth to them. married couples have often purchased "sex games" that come and go and offer no substance. Lover'sopoly touches on every level of marriage relationship from intimacy, to sex, to romance and even humor.

The players are by rolling the dice and advancing to the next space. Spaces consist of "action spaces" as well as "Pandora's Box" and "Naughty or Nice". When landing on an action space the individual has the right to purchase the space and build on the space "time chips". By purchasing more time chips they receive more time with the action when their spouse lands on it. "Padora's Box" and "Naughty or Nice" are not properties open to ownership but rather actions or questions that are fueled throughout the game and keep the game interesting and moving along. The goal is to own as many of the desired action properties but watch out because your partner may earn the right to purchase an action property right from under your nose.

The action properties are the most creative portion of the game. Ladies, how would you like to receive a nice 3 minute kneck massage every time your partner lands on your space? 
Or perhaps you wouldn’t mind your partner drawing a seductive pose of you in your birthday suite? Men, how would you like your spouse enjoying a nice dessert off of your mid-section? Or perhaps having your wife describe your most attractive features?

This game has everything for both male and female and is the perfect way to spark up a relationship. Loversopoly makes the best Valentine’s Day gift as well.

You can run but you can't hide!

The object of the game is to move Swamp Hoppers around the board, trying to avoid having them gobbled up by Zob the Blob. Players on a turn will either move their Swamp Hoppers or Zob the Blob according to the roll of the character die. The last player to have one or more Swamp Hoppers on the board at the end of the game is the winner.

It's a roll and move game there you try to catch the other players Swamp Hoppers with a large plastic monster who can swallow the Swamp Hoppers with a gentle pull when it land on the same space.

Ransack is a cut-throat board game for two players. Ransack is about two thieves, The Wolf and The Scorpion, who have challenged each other to a thieves' duel.

Both players must race to be the first to loot 11 coins from the dungeon. This is easier said than done, though, since your fate rests on the fickle nature of coin tosses.

Players take turns navigating through a dungeon that is built using tiles drawn from a central pile. Combat, events and deciding whose turn it is are all handled using coin flips.

Optional rule variants include a gambling / drinking versions. Due to the inclusion of these rules in the rule book the minimum age is set at 18.

name.value: Make Space For Puma The PRS Board Game

item.description:
Game Intention:
More space, more sales, more margin. This logic is part of our Phase 4 growth strategy. Now we want to make it happen. To be The Better Retail Partner we need to grow deeper into the world of retail. PRS provides ways and solutions to make, maintain and increase PUMA branded retail space on retailer's floors.

As growth is serious business, we decided to wrap it up in a. Game for you to play with your PRS buddies.

Each player starts with $70,000 capital and you explore the game board that shows brand environments in various retail situations. Embedded in these environments are PRS opportunities. Make money by collecting your realized solutions' operating profit each round.

To win the game, you must a) pass the collect operating profit field with b) all space opportunities of your color realized, and c) the highest operating profit (cash minus IOU and interest) of all players. Once a player calls "game over" all other players collect one round of operating profit. Continue game, if operating profit of another player is higher than that of caller...

"Meetings, hikes, choir practice, fire duty, and a baptism. All the fun, excitement, and spiritual renewal of a true to life campmeeting."

Players draw destination cards and roll the dice to proceed to that location. Upon arriving at their destination, players read and follow the instructions and when finished draw a new destination card. Players earn souls for completing tasks and arriving at destinations.

Play continues until "The Last Day of Campmeeting" card is drawn.

The player who has collected the most souls, wins that game.

item.description:
Whitetail Wilderness is a game about hunting white-tailed deer. Game play is scenario-driven, with a modular "board" of hex tiles created as per the scenario set up rules.

The specific game objective depends on the scenario, but generally requires the players to do one of the following within a specified number of game rounds:

- Shoot the biggest buck
- Shoot a specific buck
- Shoot the most deer or most total points in bucks

Players control Hunter characters as their game personas. Six pre-generated characters are included as well as blank cards for people to create their own. Each Hunter character is rated 1 to 5 on six different attributes. Event cards and player actions will test the skills of each Hunter character.

On their turn, players execute two actions from among nine different choices. The players are attempting to find a good hunting area while increasing their rating on the Deer Encounter Meter, which is a measure of progress toward finding where the deer are located. Eventually, players will execute Hunt actions in the hopes of seeing deer. Once a player determines that deer are present, the deer need to be identified and brought in close enough for a shot. As the deer move closer and the encounter continues, the alertness level of the deer will generally begin to increase as they sense danger nearby. If the players aren't careful, the deer may flee and ruin their chances for a shot.

Players have to manage their Energy levels, items, Hunter cards and save up for bonuses while staying aware of what the other players are doing and attempt to blunt their efforts where possible.

In Invasions Tuatha Dé Danann, players will storm the ancient island of Ireland as the Tuatha Dé Danann, seeking to conquer and claim the land from the Fir Bolg inhabitants. The Tuatha Dé Danann are not the only invading faction, the inbound Milesians and Fomorians will also take part in what will be a legendary war!

Players shall gather resources, fortify hill-forts, reinforce Tuathian armies, and construct megalithic stones which are essential for a Tuatha Dé Danann victory.

The invading factions seek the land for themselves, so the Tuatha Dé Danann must seek each others help, if they wish to have any chance at fending off these invasions.

Survive the invaders and the mightiest of the Tuatha Dé Danann will become King. Fail, and the Tuatha Dé Danann are history!

On each turn, players will take part in each of the Gather, Build, Training, Movement, and Exploration Phases. These phases will allow the players to use their worker units to gather the resources they need to strengthen their control of the island. These resources will be necessary during other phases, where players will be able to construct hill-forts, prepare armies for battle, and build megalithic stones to solidify the strength of the Tuatha Dé Danann across the land.

In the far distant future, the world is recovering from global devastation brought on by both nuclear and biological warfare. The area occupied by the former United States of America is one of the first land areas to experience a rebirth of civilization. Old technology is salvaged and relearned. Eight distinct regions emerge, each with its own ideals, but all predicated on peace. No one wants to repeat the mistakes of the past. Almost no one…

Over time, four Overlords emerge. Vying for wealth and power, each establishes his own ragtag army. Slowly, their minions spread throughout the eight habitable regions. Death and destruction follow in their wake as each faction battles the other for land, fuel, wealth, and power. Which will triumph over the others, bringing a final, lasting peace to the land? Only time and Thompson machine guns will tell.

The boardgame Ameritrash, like its namesake gaming genre, is an exciting, tension-filled game, rich in theme, filled with player conflict, and possessing a large amount of dice! Two to four players assume the role of an Overlord of a military faction intent on securing as much plunder and power as possible. During the span of five turns, players move their ramshackle units across the gameboard, attempting to capture objectives, pillage wealth, and weaken enemy factions.

Quick to learn and fun to play, Ameritrash is game of low to moderate complexity, and heavy firepower.

The name of the game translate from French to "Pyramid of the Pharaoh". The intro of the game says that "the game has been discovered in archaeological research in Egypt and was designed by a Pharaoh during Ancient era where he invited guests to play a game during his parties where they had to build a pyramid with hieroglyphs carved on a tablet".

It is an Egyptian theme card game based on both luck and strategy that is designed for the family with rules very easy to undestand. The goal of the game is to be the first to build his pyramid. In order to do so, the players need collect cards that represent different resources such as workers, materials, tools, administration, royal family and of course a pharaoh. Some cards have negative effect. During his turn, a player can draw a card or play a "Mystery" card which allow him to steal a card from another player, exchange a card, build his pyramid, play an extra turn or protect parts of his pyramid already built.

item.description:
Math-domino with numbers in one half of tile and operation in another half of tile.
Tiles may be placed only with different halfs touching each-other and the number-half must be answer of the operation of the other half.

Who runs out of his tiles first is the winner.

The game revolves around the changing patterns of sunspots during their approximately 11-year cycles. Each player has 11 wooden disks in one color. The circular board is divided into eleven sectors grouped into two areas: a 6-sector zone where players try to have as much sunspots as possible, and a 5-sector area, where the aim is to place as few sunspots as possible. Sunspots are represented by pips on dice faces. Each sector shows a rating number (5,8,9,10,13 or 15 in the 'max' sectors, and 9,10, 11, 13 or 17 in the 'min' sectors).

There are three standard dice to roll and ca. 60 small dice used to represent sunspots. The 11 sectors are divided into two circular annuli (outer and inner ring), one for each player.
Players alternate rolling three dice (1-3 dice can be rolled one additional time, if the player so wishes). The final three rolled values are added to produce a number of 'sunspots' that are then placed on any free sector in the player's ring. If the opponent has the same number of sunspots in the inner or outer adjacent ring, the sunspots from both sectors are removed. If both players have different number of sunspots in the two fields on a given sector, the player with the higher (in a 'max' sector) or lower (in a 'min' sector) number wins the sector, which changes the turn order so that it's now this player's turn again. At the end of the game, players add the rating values of the sectors they have won. The player with the highest rating is the winner.

Players toss the self-stick ball on the special wall-board to land on a “letter fish” or a “picture fish,” and then must answer the question about that letter or picture depending on the game.
If the answer is correct player scores a point.

f.e.: 
Toss and say the letter. “This is the letter
Toss and say a word that begins that word
Toss and say the picture word and identify its beginning sound.
etc.

Player with the most correct answers is the winner.

The Mystique Deck is a special deck of 60 cards, with each card depicting three different features (instead of two, like a regular poker deck):


 Colour: Yellow, red, and blue — the 3 primary colours of pigment. There are 20 cards of each colour.
 Suit: Suns, Moons, Arms, and Crowns. Suns and moons are the ‘heaven’ cards. Arms and Crowns are the ‘earth’ cards. There are 15 cards of each suit.
 Number: from 1 to 5. Fives are depicted with an open palm, with the corresponding coloured suit in its palm. There are 12 cards of each number.


Moreover, each card has a unique number at the top, from 1 to 60. This is the ‘card number’.

Some examples of cards are:

 Three of red crowns,
 One of blue suns (also called ace of blue suns),
 Five of yellow arms (also called palm of yellow arms)




There are two different Mystique decks: Mystique Gold and Mystique Silver. Both have the same card distribution; only the backs are different.

The Mystique Deck includes a default game also called Mystique, but the deck has been designed to be used in different future games. You will be able to download new rules from the nestorgames site as they are uploaded.

item.description:
Insurgence is an assymetric PnP two-player game that pits brave rebels against an evil empire in a futuristic capital. Or maybe it's a benevolent empire against cruel terrorists - the victor will decide.

The game is played on a 3x3 grid of tiles that make up the districts of the capital. Both players use action cards to move pawns around the districts, but they each have very different goals.

The rebels use hidden rebel cells and their rebel leader to fulfil plots by doing sabotage, making assasinations, and spreading propaganda throughout the districts. If the rebel player fulfils two out of three plots, he/she wins the game. But the rebels also work on causing uprising in the districts. This allows riots to spread from the slums towards the imperial palace. If that happens, the rebels also win.

The empire player, meanwhile, try to either uncover the plots by sorrounding cells with armies and revealing them, or to capture the rebel leader by clever use of both armies and the secret police. If the empire player uncovers all three plots or captures the leader, he/she wins.

In order to win you have to plan carefully while still being able to adapt to an unlucky draw of action cards. But most of all you'll have to both outwit and outbluff your opponent.

Mystique, the default game for The Mystique Deck, is a climbing game for 2 to 6 individual players that can be also played in pairs (4 or 6 players).

In Mystique, the players are spellcasters in combat who start each skirmish with a hand of spell cards; each card includes a number (1-5), a color (red, blue or yellow), and a suit (Suns, Moons, Arms, or Crowns). The first spellcaster opens a round by "casting a spell" – that is, she chooses up to five cards from her hand that have something in common (either the same number, the same suit, or the same color), then announces the number of cards she's chosen and what they have in common as she places them face up on the table; e.g., "three crowns" or "four yellow". The following player must either:


 Cast an equal or stronger spell of the same type as the previous player (i.e., the same number of cards — or more — with the same common feature), thereby passing the turn to the next player, or



 Take all cards that have been played during this round and place them face down in a pile next to herself. These are her "burns". This ends the round. She becomes the new "spellcaster" and opens a new round.


When a player must open a new round but has no cards in hand, the skirmish ends and the player with the fewest burns wins. Ties are possible. The game can be played to the best of three or five skirmishes. Mystique includes two advanced rules, covering "aces scoring" and "spell deflection".

item.description:
In this game players create chemical companies in order to devellop as much products as possible. During the game, the players are confronted with economical, chemical and technical questions. 
Products can be created within one of the four categories: specialties, energy, consumer products of pharmaceuticals. Through research, design, and pilot phase a final product is created and victory points are gained. 
But the competition can be hard and they can make it difficult for the player to make a return on his investment for the products he's creating. The winner is the player who dominates the world's economy by creating the most products and gaining the most victory points.

This game was created as an educational game by Identity Games International bv in collaboration with students from the Technical University of Delft (T.U.Delft) in The Netherlands and with sponsorship from multiple chemical companies. On release, a free copy was sent to almost 1000 schools in The Netherlands and Belgium.

Game Play :

Players throw the dice to move around the board. There are different types of spaces they can land on :
- Products: the player can invest in the product or go to the next stage of development, paying the fee. If another player has already invested in this product, the current player can pay him royalties or go for a hostile take-over to become the market leader.
- Chance : the player takes a chance-card and may get or lose money.
- Strategy : these cards give the players an advantage (hostile take-over, protection, Nobel-prize, investment bonus or grants).
- Start : each time the player passes start, he's paid a salary.
- Artesia (bank where the player gets money), OCenW (player gets an education and passes this round) or InterChem2000group (the dice are thrown again and the player moves further on the board).
Players obtain victory points for each fully developed product (phase 4), for each market they dominate and if they win a Nobel-prize.
The winner is the player who manages to first gain the predetermined number of victory points.

Do Your Job is a fast, family fun game. It comes with two different variants. One is a collecting game (similar to Gin Rummy or Spoons) with a twist and the other is a mind-bender with a betting mechanic.

In the original game variant, each player will attempt to obtain all the elements needed in order to complete their job from the card piles at the center of the table; they will need to find a Job card and the necessary Job Item card(s) during the game. Each turn players will draw a card from the top of a deck, discard a card face up onto a deck, and move a card from one deck to another (you may do these actions in any order, but you must do them all). If you successfully have all the cards necessary to Do Your Job at any point on your turn, you win!

Jobs are not so easily done, though. The corporate world is a cruel mistress, and the player must try to figure out the other players' jobs in order to thwart jobs being done. If people realize what job you are trying to do, desired cards can be buried within one of the decks during other players' discard or move action since you can only draw from the top of a pile.

In the Treachery game variant, each player tries to win the most points. They will accomplish this by first betting for the round. Then players will play a job card (either the Pirate or the Dwarf) and a number card face down. The pirates will then flip their bet (positive to negative or negative to positive) and switch number cards with the other players according to the arrows. Whoever has the highest number will win all the bets and play will repeat in this fashion. Be wary though, for if each person plays the Pirate, the bets will be flipped, but everyone keeps their number card.

Era of the Ninja is a game of stealth and combat in which players take on the role of ninja attempting to eliminate the lord of a castle in feudal Japan. Players may sneak through the castle or fight, but must be careful as the enemy is actively searching for them. As the players succeed, they gain ingenuity, which can be used to increase their arsenal of equipment or gain new skills for use in the search for the lord. Combat against enemy units has a wound mechanism that allows players to weaken their enemy before dealing a final blow and characters also have the use of mystical ki to help them overcome the obstacles ahead of them. Players must be careful though as the enemy gains strength in numbers. Players must find a way to survive long enough to locate defeat the lord to claim victory. In the end, only one player can be declared the victor – the one who defeats the lord!

Era of the Ninja comes with multiple levels of play from Basic for new players to Advanced, which increases the challenge for veteran players. There are also different modes of play from Regular play, True co-op mode, Death Match, Team Death Match, and Head of the Lord allowing players the ability to choose their favorite type of game and play style.

link.value: Mythical Eras of War, Games, LLC.

item.description:
In this game, you play as Derin Hawk, a dedicated soldier trying desperately to stop the enemy known as Them. They emerged long ago and have quickly destroyed the once peaceful nation. Now, you must enter the mountain from which they came, in hopes of finding a way to stop them.

After picking a mission, you will use the appropriate enemy cards and weapons. By taking cover (and you must take cover, or you WILL die) and laying strategic fire, you will be able to advance through the map. Do you use an action to move spaces, or do you cover fire? Do you take cover after you move, or stand in the open? And what weapons do you pick up or save for later?

Combat uses many dice, as you roll die equal to your power, scoring a hit for each dice equal to your accuracy. You deal the weapons damage for each hit. Enemies follow the same rules.

This is not one of those games where the enemies are weaker but more numerous. It is where the enemies are both the same as you and more numerous. Ha! Ha!

Can you save humanity?

The game where you drive your friends crazy!

Premise:
You and your friends are patients in a Asylum with nothing better to do then drive each other crazy! Every turn use different tactics to force your opponents to go insane!

Game play:
Divide the deck evenly among the players, and each turn play a card to force the other patients to discard cards from their hand or discard pile.
The game ends when there is one player left.

Contains 100 cards that can change the momentum of the game at the drop of a hat. Losing terribly? Play an unstoppable card that switches your deck with the discard pile! That will show them! Or are you tired of everyone ganging up on you? Force them to play with their hand face up! Now whose laughing!?

In this game of tactics & luck, you try to outsmart your opponent(s) by conquering their pawns, jumping yourself to your Home Zone and taking the best spots on the board.
 In this abstract game, the players try to get their pawns from their starting position in the oppenents Home zone, to their own Home Zone on the other end of the board.
This is done by throwing two dice, which have the primary colours, a black, a white & a joker side on them. By strategically using these colors you can jump forward, take over enemy pawns and get into waiting rooms or your home zone. 
The first player to get all their pawns in their Home Zone, wins the game.

Authors note.
Primary moves is actually not as abstract as it first appears once you have played it. The board appearance is random for a reason, that was how I could build player 3 and 4 into the game.

The original games relies a lot on luck and quick decision making due to the fact that the drive mech is dice.
The end of 2015 saw a "couldnt see the wood through the trees" breakthough and allowed a new mech to be added in the form of cards that turn the table on the luck factor, making it a more pleasurable game for the planners and thinkers among us, all be it still very light to play.

what still never ceases to amaze me is how many variations and styles this 1 simple game can have all based on a few super simple rules.

A taijitu is a symbol representing the balance between opposing forces. (For example, the Yin-Yang symbol is a taijitu.)

It is also the name of this two player game set on an octagonal board made of hexagons. There are three types of pieces- player one's black pieces, player two's white pieces, and a type of piece both players can use that is grey. All of these pieces start in the center of the board, connected together. Along the eight sides of the board are scoring markers called Trigrams. The first player to land one of their pieces (never the grey ones) onto four of these Trigrams wins the game.

A player's turn is to take two actions, and an action is simply moving a piece they are allowed to move to any unoccupied adjacent space. A player is allowed to move either pieces of their color or grey pieces, but with these two cardinal rules: First, they are not allowed to move any grey pieces the other player moved on their previous turn, and, second, no piece may ever be separate from the rest of the pieces at the end of any action.

When a player scores a Trigram, they flip the piece that landed on it to its other side, which now makes it a normal grey piece. This means as one player is winning, they will also have a more difficult time scoring.

This game is based on the Gears of War: Judgement game mode, Survival, in which players must survive 10 waves of Locusts.

Players pick a character; Baird, Paduk, Cole, or Sofia. After picking a map, players must start on the bottom row.

On the players turn, they can move, attack, or use their special move. Moving is simply moving one space any cardinal direction. You can attack a Locust if it is in range of a weapon you have. Or you can use a special, like Sofia's stim grenade, which revives teammates.

After players move, the Locust spawn and advance, attacking barriers that are in their way, except for the Wretch, which can leap right over them. Locusts attack following the same rules.

Combat is simple. Roll die equal to your power. Each dice equal to your accuracy scores a hit. Each hit deals the weapons damage.

Locusts have special abilities, and the rule book dictates when to use them.

Be careful. Each Locust is different. The Ticker can easily destroy barriers, and self-destruct. The Wretch can leap over barriers and climb into perches. The Drone has grenades, and Kantus heals his comrades. 
The even more powerful Locust can do things from spit acid to dig underground.

You are collecting gold nuggets from streams and rivers - and from other players also seeking for gold.
On your turn, roll 7 dice (sides: gold nugget, lasso, 2, 3, 4, 5). Then
a, roll again, but before that, freeze at least one die:
- one or more lassoes AND/OR
- one or more gold nuggets AND/OR
- three or more numbered dice showing the same number. When 3 or more numbered dice are already frozen you can freeze further dice (1 or more) of this number after the subsequent rolls.

b, if you can't freeze any die you can't take any gold nuggets and it's the other player's turn

c, if you decide to take the gold nuggets, you get 
- 1 nugget for each die showing gold nuggets
- 2/3/4/5 nuggets for 3 or more dice showing the numbers 2/3/4/5 
- and if you have 3 lassoes, you can take these gold nuggets from the other player instead of taking it from the common stock.

If you have used all your dice on your turn then it's your turn again.

The player with the most gold nuggets wins.

item.description:
Cardio Alarm is a card game, a frenzy race on hospital corridors.
Block all the entrances before the agents escape with a "secret project". For your disposal you have the hospital staff, as well as your reflexes and cunning. Who will be the fastest, wins. The box contains the elements needed to play the game, plus DVD "Blisko serca" and educational inserts. The game was created to support the "Tik Tak. Jestem na tak!" action. Purpose of the program is to raise funds for the creation of the first family of prosthetic heart for children.

The game uses a rules of the domino - with the difference that on the cards, instead of the dots are colors. In the game there are two decks of cards. One of the players is a "Hospital Ordinator" and draw three cards from the first deck. The rest of the players are "Agents" and each of them draw five cards from the second deck. Before start of the game, players put "start marker" in front of them - the task for Agents is to put as much card to it as possible. These are hospital corridors - the escape route.
“Agents” put their cards in sequence, according to the rules, trying to create the longest escape route. “Hospital Ordinator” - playing in real time - with staff and special cards will try to block all the exits. The game ends at the moment in which the agents can no longer put any card, or the "Ordinator" isn't be able to draw a card.
At the end, players count how many cards is put as an escape route and nominate another player to become an "Hospital Ordinator". Which player ends with the least number of corridors - win the game.

Animal Matching Game similar to Go Fish!

Be the first to match the animals to their sounds. Players take turns asking for animals or the sounds those animals make. Tricks are sets of three (two sounds and one animal). The game plays fast and fun, testing your memory.

Animals and sounds are in English and French and the game comes with a special bilingual guide card. French instructions are forthcoming.

Simple quiz game for German football fans. The host/hostess (probably Mum or Dad in this case) sets a time limit and the one with the most correct answers when time runs out, wins.

There are 50 cards with two questions per card and answers on the reverse. Questions aimed at kids so won't be too taxing.

Description: 
Chess King is a perpetual puzzle game of speed and ingenuity. Chess King has many of the same elements of chess, but it’s not chess! With each move you make, Chess King will enhance your ability to think quickly and precisely, exercising your mind to keep it sharp. What makes Chess King exciting is after the first puzzle is completed, each additional puzzle is created by your own hand. The combination of various puzzles, time restrictions and Chess-King Locks, will make this game a fun and challenging pastime.

The Object of the Game:
The object of the game is to reach the Chess King Square before your opponent by successfully completing each puzzle (Three rotations with the King), without encountering a Chess-King Lock, before three minutes elapses.

A game characterizing the oldest and largest industry known to mankind.

From the Introduction: "This game was designed with as much reality as possible to depict the actualities of farming. It is impossible to inject all the complexities of modern-day farming into this game, yet it does contain enough reality to be educational to the nonfarming-oriented person and at the same time provide a competitive and fun atmosphere for all. As you play the game, you can to some degree sense the frustrations that farmers face but yet realize the real competitive situation that farming has come to be, neighbor versus neighbor and, likewise, player versus player. You might note that virtually all the option positions in the game are akin to decisions that farmers must make. While playing the game you will find that what you thought was the best decision would later not be so, as the real life farmer has experienced so many times. Another likeness of the game to farming is that your destiny depends on when and where you are."

From the Object of the Game: "The object of the game is to buy and sell production as each player takes his turn. Production is defined as Corn, Soybeans, Wheat Cows, and Hogs. Commodities are defined as Corn, Wheat, and Soybeans. Livestock is defined as Cows and Hogs. Each player should try to buy as cheaply as possible and sell as high as possible as he stops on various spots around the board in order to accumulate the enough money to buy all the production that belongs on a player's farm. Players should keep in mind that they must make several transactions in order to buy their production and, at the same time, retain enough assets to take care of the expenses that will surely come their way. The first play to buy all production for their farm is the winner. Each farm's production consists of 1 bin of Wheat, 1 bin of Corn, 1 bin of Soybeans, 1 Cow, and 1 Hog. Bins are identified by colors. Yellow represents Corn bins, Light Gold represents Soybean bins, and Dark Gold represents Wheat bins. As a player buys these commodities, he may place them in their respective places on the board and, likewise, the same for livestock."

Rock, Paper, Scissors, BANG! is an abstract two-player strategy game played on a 5x5 board. Each player has twelve pieces: three each of Rock, Paper, Scissors and Dynamite. The game is played in two parts:


 Part 1: Players take turns placing individual pieces on the board.
 Part 2: Players take turns moving pieces to make towers, moving towers to make bigger towers, and moving dynamite to remove pieces and towers from the board.


If both players "pass" consecutively or neither player can make a move, the game ends. Each player scores all of his towers, with each tower being worth a number of points equal to its height minus 1. Whoever has the highest score wins.

item.description:
Taken from the instruction sheet:

"Taffy's four party scenes are shown on the board - but where are the guests? Each player is Taffy, trying to be the "hostess with the mostest" by making the right scene with the right guests.
 Players start with random guest cards for all the parties. You make the party rounds according to your calls on the telephone. The spaces on the board match the shapes of the guest cards. Whenever you land in a space for which you have a guest card for a matching shape, you must place that guest in the space. Funny scenes will develop, such as pajamas appearing at the formal party, guests in bathing suits frolicking in the snow, etc.
 Whenever you are able to take the correct guest to the correct party, you receive a picture card. The WINNER is the player who can show she is the best hostess by placing the most guests correctly and collecting the most pictures."

The game re-creates the Battle of Ravenna, fought on 11 April 1512 (tragic Easter day), by forces of the Holy League and France. The players are divided into two camps and guide the opposing armies with the sole purpose of defeating the opponent.
This game introduces a new mechanic like referring to a real circumstance. At that time give orders in battle was very difficult and in the chain of command it happened that someone not obey to the orders: the same thing will happen in the game where each team can decide whether and when to comply with an order.

LEADERS: A Combined Game, the first title from rudy games GmbH, combines classic game elements with the opportunities offered by the modern technologies found in smart devices.

This strategy game takes up to six players back to the Cold War era, with each player striving to attain world domination. In the game, you'll use skillful diplomacy to forge powerful alliances, research ground-breaking technologies to give yourself the decisive edge, dispatch secret agents to procure classified information about your opponents, participate in missions on behalf of the international community, and demonstrate your military power and conquer new areas.

Thanks to the incorporation of a smart device in this design, LEADERS: A Combined Game enables a complex economy, involved research threads, and clandestine interactions with other players such as espionage or sabotage.

ATTENTION: The "LEADERS" video game/app is required for playing!

name.value: Koi Pond: A Coy Card Game

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

Koi Pond: A Coy Card Game is a lovely, clever game for 2-4 players. Collect colorful koi fish and choose whether to place them in your pond or in your house. You'll score points only for the *lower* number, though, so keep your pond and house as balanced as you can. Your pond is public, but your house is secret. To win, you have to be...coy!

Each turn, players take turns drawing a card from the face-down deck or from the face-up "lake" until everyone has three new cards in hand. Then all players simultaneously choose from amongst their entire hand one card to add to their personal pond and one to discard to their personal "river". Cards in your river will eventually go to the lake, so choose carefully.

After six turns, the round ends. Score points by comparing the total number of koi of a suit in your pond and your house. Score points equal to the *lower* number. Score each suit of koi in this manner. If a crane, housecat or turtle is in your pond, you score bonus points for koi of that noted suit in your opponent's pond (crane), house (housecat) or river (turtle). Which opponent depends on the number of players and the current round.

After each round, ribbons are awarded to the player with the most koi of each suit in her river. Ribbons grant bonus points at the end of the game.

To maximize your koi score, you have to carefully balance the populations in your pond and house. A turtle, housecat, or crane earns points from an opponent's hard work, but they also take valuable space in your hand. Sending high value koi cards to your river earns more ribbons, but also makes them available to all players in the next round. The player with the most points wins!

Skelit's Revenge....the most feared ship on the high seas....and you've finally taken it. Captain Fromm and his skeleton crew have amassed a massive treasure, and now is your chance to take it all. Players take on the role of Pirates who are boarding Skelit's Revenge for one purpose....to take the loot. They must battle the flames, the skeleton crew, and their own fatigue if they hope to make it out alive.

Dead Men Tell No Tales is a co-operative game for 2-5 players. The game uses the common Action Point system to determine what a player does on their turn...with a twist. As players work together, they can pass their Actions on to their teammates in order to best utilize the assets that they have. Players will build the board as they play, ensuring that no two games will ever be alike. As they search the ship for the Treasure, they will encounter Enemies and Guards that they must battle, along with various items that will help them in their quest. all the while, battling the inferno that resulted when they took over the ship. Unique systems for tracking fire, enemy movement, and a player’s fatigue all combine into an interesting and unique cooperative gaming experience.

Do you and your crew have what it takes to make off with all of the treasure and live to tell the story? Or are you going down with the ship in Dead Men Tell No Tales?

item.description:
Ever wanted to make your friend bark like a dog three times, while rubbing their belly and slapping their knee? Then we have the perfect game for you!

Rules Lawyer, by designer Nathan Hansen, is a fast-paced, light-hearted, family-fun card game for 3 or more players with ever-changing rules. Each player takes turns altering and then obeying the current rules ("Laws") of the game.

Your goal is to fulfill three Goal cards in your hand, therefore you must change the Laws (or hope someone else does) to your advantage. But beware, if you – or someone you spot – doesn't perform all of the Laws correctly or in order, you may lose some of your Goal cards, or players could steal Goal cards from you!

Great for parties, family, and friends, see what rules you can come up with in Rules Lawyer!

Complexity: 2 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 2 on a 9 scale

Bombinoes is a game of creative connections. During the game you have tiles and attempt to form them into a line. However, all the tiles have images on them and placing a tile requires you to come up with what the tile has in common with the tile next to it. A cloud and an umbrella might be connected by "rain," for instance, while a criminal and coffee might be connected by "words starting with C." You're only able to use any kind of connection once in your line, and your opponent might break up your line with a bomb tile and force you to rethink connections on the fly, so making the 10 connections you need to win the game will take an agile mind and a creative spirit!

Game description from the publisher:

Be the first to get rid of all of your dice in Pass the Pandas by rolling pandas, bamboo, or water drops. A player who rolls pandas on her turn is able to pass those dice to other players. A roll of bamboo must be matched (or exceeded!) by the next player. A roll of water allows her to discard those dice. A blank roll does nothing to help her, and she must keep blank dice to roll again on her next turn. Pandas!

item.description:
What the Food?! is a fast-paced card game for 3-8 players capturing the experience of a classic cafeteria food fight! Pick up food, throw funny combos at your opponents and duck to avoid "humiliation" points from flying food impact.

In the center is a draw deck, with five food or other cards exposed at any one time to make up the "cafeteria floor". Players start the game with three standard actions and one special action unique to their character. Every round, each player chooses three of their action cards, and puts them in a stack representing the next three turns. The turns are then resolved at once, but in clockwise rotation to handle any timing conflicts. Players can gain additional actions during the game, and global school events occur, instantly causing random chaos.

When any player reaches 10 humiliation points, someone has "alerted the principal" and the fight is over at the end of that round. The winner is the person with the LOWEST humiliation score.

name.value: Great War at Sea: Russo-Japanese War

item.description:
From the Avalanche Press website:

Japan entered the modern age in 1868, with a new young emperor determined to make his island nation a world power. After decades of steady progress, Japan began its own practice of colonialism, defeating China in 1894. As the Japanese began to infiltrate the semi-independent Kingdom of Korea, they ran into Russian agents doing the same. Despite Japanese offers to negotiate, elements within the Russian Empire were set on war.

Great War at Sea: Russo-Japanese War covers the naval aspects of the resulting conflict, which opened with a Japanese surprise attack on the Russian Pacific Fleet’s base at Port Arthur in northern China. There are 50 scenarios, including the climactic Battle of Tsushima, as well as hypothetical actions ranging from an early dispute resulting from the 1895 "Triple Intervention" to a showdown in 1906 with greatly reinforced Russian and Japanese fleets.

The Russian fleet is a mixed bag of modern battleships and ancient ironclads better suited for a museum. The Pacific Fleet that begins the game in the Far East has modern ships stationed at Port Arthur and a cruiser squadron in Vladivostok. Between them lies Korea, occupied by Japan. The Russian strategic situation is difficult.

The Japanese have a better fleet; though not as large, their armored cruisers outclass their Russian counterparts and their torpedo boats are more numerous and more effective. They are also better-led after the death of the Russian Admiral Makarov.

The map covers the Japanese home islands and the seas around them. As with other games in the series, it’s divided into zones 32 miles across. Fleets attempt to locate one another on this map. When contact is made, play moves to a tactical map where ships maneuver and fight.

The previous edition of this game (Great War at Sea: 1904-1905) won the Origins Award for Best Historical Game due to play balance and simplicity. Without aircraft, play is even faster than in other games in the series. The strategic situation is challenging to both players, and competitive balance is keen without sacrificing the historical accuracy of the game as a simulation. Unlike most wars, the Russo-Japanese naval war took place between opponents reasonably matched in terms of vessels and numbers (albeit not in training), and that makes for a tense and exciting game.

Russo-Japanese War includes:
• One 34 x 22-inch operational map
• One 22 x 22-inch tactical map
• 210 playing pieces
• A game booklet including 50 scenarios

item.description:
A simpler version of Shogi (or a more complex version of Let's Catch the Lion! (aka DÅbutsu ShÅgi or animal shogi), using the illustrations and look of the latter).

Every player has just 8 pieces (3 chicks, 2 cats, 2 dogs and 1 lion) and try to catch the opponents lion. The board is 5x6 squares, so it's a shorter game than regular Shogi, aimed at getting children even more interested in Shogi after they've outgrown the original DÅbutsu ShÅgi.

Goro-Goro Dobutsu Shogi not only has a bigger board compared to Dobutsu Shogi, it also adds in some more rules of the full Shogi game:
- Reaching the other side of the board with your lion no longer wins you the game. Only capturing your opponent's lion does.
- You can't have two of your own chicks in the same column/file.
- You can't drop a chick for mate.

Taken from the publisher's website:

The cute animal pieces are now combined with Goro-Goro Shogi, a small shogi on 5x6 square board. This is a very good next step for everyone who has played Dobutsu Shogi.

The rules of Goro-Goro Shogi was invented by Japan Shogi Association, and is widely known to be a very good variation of shogi to learn important concepts in shogi, such as handling the generals effectively, importance of promoting a pawn, and mating the opponent's king with successive piece drops.

Cats and dogs run and play in this small board. Highly recommended. Please have fun!

item.description:
Card game published by a German private health care company.

Deal out all the cards. You must play a card to the middle of the table if you can. A legal card to play is any card to a sport if that sport has never been played before. Or a legal play is to play the next card to a card already on the table but the card played must be the number above the sport card you want to play or the one under:
For example:
Let us say that on the table is No. 4 Watersport. A legal play to this card would be the Watersport card numbered 5 or 3. If one of these is played, the next player could play a Watersport card if he chose, provided it was numbered one below or one up again. There is one Champion card which serves as a Joker.

When a card is played by any player, score the points for that player on the card (same as the number) and record this on a score-sheet. The cards rank from 1 to 6 and there are 5 different sports possible in play.

The winner is the first to use all their cards.

Young children's educational game.

There are 12 different mini-boards, each consisting of five jigsaw-type pieces. There are five versions of play which can be intended for different age groups. All the games though relate to collecting pieces and forming complete boards. The games range from very simple where the players do little more than to complete 5 mini-boards each. The gameplay is negligible, Mum just piles up the pieces and then the children look for the pieces they are interest in.

And so each game adds a little more gameplay, ending with a game for three players where the pieces are traded back and forth. The winner is still the one who completes their assigned boards first.

An old track game that depicts the players rise through the Boy Scouts. Players start at "start here" location on the outer circle track. After spinning, player move the indicated amount. The first player, reaches the center space on the board win the game.
Beautifully color illustrated 18½" x 18½" game board, with four colored wooden pieces and two cardboard spinners with metal arrows. The original instructions were printed on the underside of the cover.

The game board contains 100, 1-3/8" colored circles, most showing boys working their way up from Tenderfoot through the stages of Scouting. The term "Eagle Scout" badge was in existence for only one year before this game was issued which is probably why it's not listed. 57 Merit Badges were available to choose from. These are listed in the text-circles. Each corner provides a detailed illustration of some facet of scouting. The exterior of the board is pressed with scrollwork in all eight corners. 
The 20" x 10" box itself is wooden and lined with a textured leather-like material.

There are cards with different animals and syllables with set of three f.e. gi-raf-fe.
Who first finds all three syllables and sets the animal names together gets the cards.
Player with the most sets is the winner.

The Times Su Doku is a tile placement game which allows either solo puzzle solving or two player competitive game play. Su Doku (or Sudoku) is a mathematical puzzle which consists of a grid of 9 3x3 squares. The completed puzzle has the digits 1 to 9 in each 3x3 square and the digits 1 to 9 in each row and column in the grid. The game poses a number of partially complete grids which must be completed correctly and can be used in either the solo puzzle or two player game.

The solo mode allows a player to attempt to correctly complete a Su Doku. This function of the set is not technically a game and is actually solo puzzle solving.

The two player mode sees both players attempting to complete the same puzzle in the same grid. Players may place a tile as soon as they are sure that the placement is correct; there is no turn sequence. The players race to place as many correct tiles as possible before the whole puzzle is complete. The winning player is the one who placed the largest number of correct tiles in the puzzle, less the number of incorrect tiles which they placed. The tiles are double sided and are printed with a different colour on each side to allow players to identify which tiles were placed by which player.

It's Rocket Festival in Junktown! This is the time of year when the mayor awards medals to everyday folks for building and launching rockets using the abundant scrap lying around town. Everyone loves Rocket Festival, but no one loves it more than those hungry little gremlins. That's because there are tons of tasty rockets to munch! As soon as you think you have a prize-winning rocket, a horde of ravenous gremlins just might sweep through and leave you with nothing! So launch those rockets fast, because when the festival ends, who ever has the best medal collection wins!

No Good Gremlins is a family card game for two to five players. Use your turn to start construction on new rockets or build up the ones you already have. Completed rockets can be launched for points, but the bigger the rocket, the more points it will earn. Be careful though! The longer you wait to launch a rocket, the greater the chance it will be eaten by gremlins.

item.description:
Children's game intended to teach road safety, particularly for young cyclists.

The board reflects a ride through town and ends where you started from. A dice is used for movement but has some choices if you are lucky. If you roll an arrow, you can advance up to 4 spaces. If you roll a card, you draw a card and another player asks you the question. If you are correct, you can move up to 6 spaces. If you roll the pedestrian, you can move him. He is an extra piece on the board and can 'walk' from zebra crossing to zebra crossing. If he is on a crossing when your piece arrives before it, you cannot go over the crossing until the pedestrian has been moved elsewhere.

The first player to arrive home, wins.

One nice touch is that the question cards can be sorted in to four levels of difficulty, so the game can happily be played by various age groups.

This letter tile game has been described as a mix between Tetris and Scrabble. 48 tiles are drawn in a random sequence and "dropped" into a slanted 7x7 playing field with the goal of creating as many and as long words as possible, horizontally and vertically. The 49th joker tile is available to be dropped at any time.

After its original release, the game has been implemented several times as computer games and web applications (often but not always titled WOW: Word on Word), with seeded tile sequences to facilitate competitive play.

From Patch's website:

"Heat up game night with this sizzling dice game! Toss the one-of-a-kind dice into the innovative Twist & Tumble Dice Cup, twist, and watch the dice tumble out! Create a line of color or number matches that will score big or make others lose big. In this game, you definitely want to Shizzle, and it’s better if you don’t fizzle!"

Players take turn rolling the dice and try to create a line of dice where the next die in line matches the previous by color or number. The more dice in your line, the more points you earn! You can reroll unused dice as many times as you want as long as you're always adding to the line. If not, you choke and lose all the points you've earned that turn.

The game ends when the bank is out of chips. The player with the most points at the end wins.

A Study in Emerald is a game for two to five players based on the award-winning short story of the same name by Neil Gaiman. In this stylistic mash-up of Sherlock Holmes and H.P. Lovecraft, the worst has already happened and the world is now ruled by the Old Ones. However, a secret war is being fought to free mankind from their servitude. The game A Study in Emerald fleshes out this core idea by including historical figures from the late nineteenth century, most being persons involved in the anarchist movement of the time.

Deck-building forms the core of the game. You use influence cubes to bid for the right to draft cards and take control of cities. Each player has a secret identity, either a Restorationist fighting against the creatures or a Loyalist attempting to defend the status quo. Which side you are on determines what you score points for. An additional twist is that the performance of other players on the same side as you can stop you from winning if they are doing particularly badly, so you really want to know who is on which side. More specifically, when the game ends – and this can result from multiple causes, such as a marker on the War or Revolution track hitting 15 or the assassination of a Restorationist player agent – then the sides compare their scores; which side has the lowest score automatically loses, then the player with the highest score on the remaining team wins the game.

The game takes around ninety minutes to play and is more complex than most, so more suitable for the experienced gamer.

name.value: Killer Bunnies: Heroes vs. Villains – Blue Starter Deck

item.description:
Killer Bunnies: Heroes vs. Villains - Blue Starter Deck is a standalone game in the Killer Bunnies universe. Drawing and playing cards from a shared deck, players may choose to be a defender of goodness, courageousness and virtue by playing the Hero Super Bunnies or a generator of chaos, evilness and deceit by playing the Villain Super Bunnies. Whoever they are, the players use their bunnies' powers to build cities, attack opponents, and protect themselves. The first player who has a predetermined number of bunnies in the Bunny Circle and cities in the City Circle wins!

Killer Bunnies: Heroes vs. Villains - Blue Starter Deck is compatible with Killer Bunnies and the Ultimate Odyssey; the deck in this game may be used as the yellow, blue, and green E-decks in that game. Though this game is for four players; equipment is only provided for three players under Odyssey's rules, as there are only three colors represented in this game.

Business Guru is effectively an Indian variant of Monopoly.

Players buy and sell property, build houses and hotels, and collect rent from their fellow players. Properties, however, are entire nations, rather than pieces of real estate. Airlines and shipping lines also replace railways in Business Guru.

There are other small differences, but the roll-and-move system is very reminiscent of Monopoly-style games.

Million Dollar Idea is a roll-and-move game where players try to become the most successful (and thereby wealthiest) businessmen through entrepreneurship. The game board has three concentric circles around which the players must move their pawns (by rolling dice) to progress through the game.

The outer circle represents "starting up your business". By landing on the various spaces of this circle, players must complete certain tasks through negotiation and by drawing cards before moving on to the second circle.

The second circle (referred to as the "inner circle") represents "operating your business". Players move their pawns through this circle in a similar manner to the outer circle.

When a player has accumulated sufficient wealth and experience from game spaces, cards, and negotiations, he may move to the "inner path and winner's circle". If a player has completed the requirements for wealth and experience ahead of his opponents, he moves to the winner's circle and wins the game.

From the game box:

"Million Dollar Idea is an exciting new board game in which players escape the corporate rut and exercise their entrepreneurial spirit. In Million Dollar Idea you market your own 'great idea' by forming a company, obtaining financing and making money through the sales of your invention. Unfortunately while you strive for success, dilemmas such as competitors who steal your ideas, union problems, lawsuits, and the ever-present threat of a hostile take-over test your business acumen while doubling your blood pressure."

Final Lap: the card game is a standalone card game that challenges up to 6 players (can be played solo) to lead their team to victory in the racing championship. A challenging card game with a great balance of skill and luck, and lots of interesting card combinations. Average play time is around 10 minutes per race, with the players deciding how many races they want to play in order to decide the championship winner, allowing Final Lap to be played as a time filler, or an entire evening of entertainment.

Players each manage a racing team of two cars and compete in a number of races through to see who can accumulate the most championship points and become the champion. In each race players need to correctly manage their hand of cards, reaping the biggest rewards possible from their good cards, and reducing the negative imapct suffered from their bad ones, to ensure the cars in their team score as many championship points as possible.

Championship points are only scored in a race by the cars that finish in the top 6 positions. At the beginning of each race the cars are laid out in the reverse finishing order from the previous race. Each player is dealt a hand of cards and during a race a player must use all of the cards in their hand. As a car finishing in last place will ensure that it begins qualifying in the following race in first position, it is therefore beneficial for cars to finish as low as possible in a race if they do not finish in the top 6 positions, which results some very interesting and tactical game play.

After the cars are laid out in order at the beginning of a race, and players have received their hand of cards, qualifying will take place. Certain cards can be used during qualifying or during a race. If a player uses a card during qualifying to improve the qualifying order of one or both of their cars, they will discard the card and draw a random card to replace it. Since players must use all of the cards in their hand during a race, they will need to evaluate whether they can afford to use such cards during qualifying as it may result it them drawing a very bad card as a replacement.

During a race players can have their cars take pit stops. When a car takes it pit stop it allows the players to discard a card from their hand without having to play it, which acts as an outlet to remove bad cards from a players hand. Pit stops need to be managed effectively as they can only be taken by cars that require them, and any cards not discarded through pit stops must be played even if they have severely negative consequences for your cars.

Excellent hand management is crucial in this game. After you receive your hand of cards you need to formulate a race plan, working out how to get the most out of the cards you’ve been dealt. Adaptability is also key, being able to change a race plan or abandon it altogether as interactions with other players may not go as expected.

Final Lap is a hugely flavourful card game, with a whole range of racing events covered by cards, including qualifying, pit stops, crashes, oil spills, spin outs, tyre punctures, yellow flags, team orders, defensive lines, slip streaming, car setup, racing strategies, repairs and mechanical problems with engines and gear boxes.

name.value: Plus und Minus bis 100: Memo Spiel

item.description:
Like in usual Memory players look for pair of tiles but instead of similar tiles there is a mathematical operation on one tile and answer on another tile to look for in this game.

Player with the most pairs at the end of the game is the winner.

"Quantities and sizes"
Like in usual Memory players look for pair of tiles but instead of similar tiles there is a similar types but different quantities or sizes on tiles to look for in this game.
f.e. player must match pair with 10 minutes and 600 seconds.

Player with the most pairs at the end of the game is the winner.

a, e, i, o, u - who hears what words have the same vowels?

Players may play the card on the middle stack if the word on that card he/she plays has the same vowel if the word on the topmost card.

Player who first gets rid of his cards is the winner.

item.description:

German language "S"-sensitive spelling card game.

Who sets four words with "ss" or "ß" first wins the game.

name.value: Cityspiel Münster: Wer ist der cleverste Unternehmensgründer der Stadt?

item.description:
A city marketing game supported by the city of Münster featuring many of the city's companies. Intended to playfully get to know the city (and the companies).

According to the back cover, luck and tactics are decisive in this game.

Here is what the rules say about the goal of the game:

"Es wird der beste Unternehmensgründer in der Stadt gesucht. Dazu müssen Unternehmenslogos schnell und geschickt auf dem Stadtplan aufgebaut werden. Wer dabei seine gegründeten Unternehmen sinnvoll erweitert und vielleicht sogar fremde Unternehmen übernehmen kann, gehört zu den ersten Anwärtern auf den Sieg."

English translation:

We are looking for the best founder of companies in town. The logos of companies have to be quickly and cleverly built on the city map. He who expands his founded companies sensibly and maybe even takes over opponent's companies is among the first candidates for victory.

Additional information:

The game board is a map of the city of Münster. Players move based on which of four movement symbols they roll on a six-sided die (by foot, bike, car or bus). On the remaining two symbols, event cards are drawn. Players can expand or take over companies by reaching adjacent areas. In the end, they score victory points for the number and size of their companies and for the majority of companies in each of the four quadrants of the map.

item.description:
Cluedo "Drei Fragezeichen": This is a variant on the famous whodunnit detective game (called Cluedo in the UK, Clue in the US) especially for younger children to play.

In this variant players move between different places fans of the three investigators will surely notice. 6 different items have disappeared in Rocky Beach, but only one of these has really been stolen. Players try to find out which item was stolen by which person and where. For this you take over the role of the three investigators and their friends - Aunt Mathilda, Inspector Cotta and Uncle Titus. Every character has a special ability which can be used once per game (e.g. move a second time). Just like in the original version, players move on the board. As soon as they enter a room/place, they can ask questions about the crime. Each player has a certain amount of cards in his hand, 3 cards have been put to the side - they say where the crime took place, who the thief is and which item was stolen. It's the players' goal to solve the crime. With the help of questions and your cards, you try to find out as much as possible about the case so that you will be the one to solve the mystery in the end and predict which cards have been set aside.
All items, characters and places are based on the adventures of the three investigators. The place where you can solve the mystery, for example, is the old house trainer in Uncle Titus' salvage yard. Amongst the criminals players can find the investigators' arch enemy Skinny Norris, for example.

Bibi Blocksberg and her friends know that their favourite horse Sabrina has had a foal so they leave the village of Martinshof to see the new arrival. But Sabrina and foal are missing.

Players move by a die roll although there are lots of choices (take this path or take that path, etc.). They must collect different pieces of equipment (Sugar, Hay, Reins and Saddle) which they will need if they are to take the missing pair with them. Certain spaces require the drawing of an Event card and the instructions must be followed (sometimes it could mean that all players are affected).

The first player to get Sabrina and the Foal back to Martinshof wins.

The name of the game is Walled City attributed to the Battle of Troy.

Walled City is a simple strategy breakthrough game in which the players try to capture opponent's home city. There are 4 small red tiles that are placed in the center of the table to form the wall. The side of the wall facing each player is their inner wall. The inner wall extends to an imaginary horizontal line. The space before the inner wall is the player's home city.

Both players have 11 Warrior pieces: the Trojan Horse (1 big square tile), the cavalry unit ( 1 of 1x1 tile, 1 of 2x1 tiles, 1 of 1x2 tile), the swordsmen (1 of 1x1 tile, 1 of 2x1 tile, 1 of 1x12 tile), the spearmen (2 of 1x1), the archer (1 of 1x1), and the king (1x1). The actions that may be available to the warriors are:
 - Move a tile in one-space
 - Move a tile in a straight-line
 - Move a tile over on the other side 
The game starts by placing the 4 red tiles to form the wall. After which, players then take turn to either place or move any of their tiles. The Trojan Horse may be introduced any time but it must be placed first behind the player's inner wall. The Trojan Horse takes on the characteristics of any piece of the same color it touches at the time. The swordsmen can move up to three one-spaces. The cavalry can play one of the actions per turn. The spearmen can be placed to any free side of a piece orthogonally adjacent to the spearmen tile. The archer can play one or two actions per turn. The king can have a series of actions per turn but these actions can only be done on the pieces of the same color. Each piece must link to another piece at all time and at least one side of the Trojan Horse piece must be free after each turn.

The game ends with the first Trojan Horse to get into the opponent's home city.

Unusual game intended for a communist state as East Germany was at the ime.

Players start with 10,000 Deutschmarks. The board has a long track that, at times, offers a short or long route (and on two places a third track is offered). Movement is by a die.

At several points there are numbers. These numbers relate to cards (there are thus 26 cards and 26 special spaces). Before you start on a short or longer path, you can look at the numbers on such a track. This might imfluence your decision. A general rule is that the longer the track taken, the more your money is secure. However there are bonuses to be earned by finishing the track quickly. So you must balance speed against risk.

After all the players have finished, money is counted up and the player with the most Deutschmarks, wins.

This is a game produced under the name "a Little Golden Game" by the Golden Books publisher.
A game for 2 to 4 Players ages 5 to 8.

In the game Three Little Pigs, one player is the wolf and the other players are pigs. The players will take turns spinning and moving their pieces on the board to the next matching color of the spinner. If a pig lands on a path leading to a house, they hide in that house. If the wolf lands on a path leading to a house (straw or stick) he blows it down.
The wolf player wins if he successfully blows down the straw and stick houses. The pig player(s) wins if he successfully hides all three of his pigs.

This is a game produced by Golden Books under the name "a Little Golden Game". 
A game for 2 to 4 players ages 5 to 8.

This is a children's game that touches on a type of memory game.
Players start with a Scoring Board in front of them. In turn, players will announce "Heads" or "Tails" and flip over one of the Animal Cards in the center of the table. If they called the correct animal part (heads or tails) they get to keep that Animal Card and take another turn. 
When they get the matching head and tail of an animal, they place the completed animal on their Scoring Card.

The Cheapass Games Poker Suite compiles several games designed by James Ernest (and sometimes others) for play with traditional playing cards. Some were previously published, some were not. Despite the name, few of the games bear much relation to the Poker family of games.

Each game has its own entry on BGG.

link.value: The Lost Pueblo of Doctor Green

item.description:
In CrossWays players want to be the first to build a path of their pieces from one side of the game board to the opposite side, but to build they need to use the cards they draw and have in hand.

On a turn, a player can lay down a single card (e.g., a red 9) and place one of their pieces on this space on the game board; she can also lay down a pair of cards with the same value and place two of her pieces in a stack on any space, including the white ones that are otherwise off-limits. If a player has two pieces in a row on a stack, no one else can play on top of that stack – but by playing a suited run of cards, a player can remove pieces already on the board, putting those spaces into play once again.

You are a paperback author trying to finish novels for your editor. Complete Westerns, Science Fiction, Romance or even the rare Best-Seller. Live the dream — and maybe pay the bills.

Word-building meets deck-building in the unique game Paperback. Players start with a deck of letter cards and wild cards. Each hand they form words, and purchase more powerful letters based on how well their word scored. Most letters have abilities that activate when they are used in a word, such as drawing more cards or double letter score. Players buy wilds to gain victory points. Variant included for cooperative play.

item.description:
The west is yours to take — if you’re strong enough to take it! You are a prospector from humble beginnings who has journeyed far and wide in search of your fortune. With only a few tools and basic resources, you start mining in hopes of striking it rich. In this wild west, gold-mining, city-building card game, you quickly find that you must be tenacious!

There’s only so much gold in the hills and you must compete with rival prospectors to claim it. This deckbuilding game starts out relatively simple and becomes progressively more complex. Players begin the game with identical decks of cards that consist of basic resources such as labor, brick, lumber, food, and silver. They can use silver and eventually gold to trade these resources for more advanced resources in the market such as pickaxe, guns, leather, and paper. Different combinations of these resources allow players to purchase event cards, wanted cards, and building cards. As a result, these cards give individuals easier access to gold and provide a specified number of victory points.

To outmatch your opponents, your strategy may consist of cunning intellect or brutal aggression. Be the architect of a sluice box, which reduces the amount of labor needed to mine gold, or build a gangster hideout to attack your opponents. When all of the gold is mined, the player with the most victory points wins and becomes the legendary boomtown tycoon!

From the back of the box:

A hospital census is a report showing each patient’s name, diagnosis, and bed number. Managers have an endless battle on their hands moving patients from the waiting room into appropriate beds.

In Census, each player builds a unique hospital by fundraising, buying different types of beds and equipment, and hiring doctors. Each year the hospitals grow, but the number of patients coming for help grows as well.

Successful hospitals will win awards – and the ability to shut down opposing players’ beds! Poorly managed hospitals will begin to see their patients pile up in the waiting room, and stolen away by other hospitals! Do you have what it takes to keep your hospital running smoothly, outshining your competitors? Grab your Census today and find out!
